item.title: New Publication Out
item.dc:creator: Martin Sterchi
item.description:
Together with my colleagues Emily Raubach and Lorenz Hilfiker, I have published a new paper in the Elsevier journal Data in Brief. The article presents the different network representations that I previously introduced on my blog. The journalâ€™s purpose is to make research datasets accessible to the community by providing the data as well as documentation and metadata in a clear and structured way.

In our paper, we describe the four network representations in detail, explain how the raw data were processed to construct them, and provide some initial descriptive analyses. Our hope is that this work will make the datasets more useful to others and encourage their application in a variety of research contexts.

We also plan to build on these datasets in our own future work. One direction we are particularly excited about is combining the networks with a metapopulation disease model for Switzerland. For some time, I have wanted to explore whether the effect of public transportation on the spread of the flu through the country can be measured.

Full citation:

Sterchi, M., Raubach, E., Hilfiker, L. (2025). SwissRailNet: Four representations of a spatially embedded railway network dataset. Data in Brief, 63, 112266. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dib.2025.112266

item.title: NetSci 2025, here we come
item.dc:creator: Martin Sterchi
item.description:
My colleague Lorenz Hilfiker and I have been accepted for a poster presentation at NetSci2025! We look forward to traveling to Maastricht (NL) this June to share our work with experts in the field.

Our research explores the potential of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for epidemic source detectionâ€”identifying the origin of an outbreak given a contact network and the epidemic states of all nodes.

Our (still preliminary) findings suggest that GNNs may not yet live up to their promise, as they are consistently outperformed by more traditional source detection methods. However, we have only explored a small region of the GNN design space so far, so it is too early to rule them out as a valuable tool for this problem.

item.title: New SNSF project
item.dc:creator: Martin Sterchi
item.description:
In March 2024, my colleagues Lorenz Hilfiker, Matthias Templ, and I submitted a project proposal to the Swiss National Science Foundationâ€™s (SNSF) second Health and Wellbeing Call.

In November 2024, we received the exciting news that our project has been awarded funding! With a grant of CHF 391,938, we will be able to hire a full-time PhD student to support our research. Additionally, Lorenz will join Matthias and me at Fachhochschule Nordwestschweiz (FHNW) in 2025, starting in a part-time position.

Over the next four years, our teamâ€”including the PhD studentâ€”will work on developing new methods to trace the origins of epidemic outbreaks in contact networks. While researchers have been exploring epidemic source detection for about 15 years, many existing studies focus on simplified models and small networks, limiting their practical applications. Our project aims to address these challenges by pursuing two key goals:

  • Scalability: Developing methods that can be applied to large-scale contact networks.

  • Real-world applicability: Designing techniques that account for uncertainty in key parameters, making them more suitable for practical use.

Our research is not limited to human pandemicsâ€”it also has significant applications in the agricultural and livestock industries, where regulatory requirements often ensure the availability of contact data.

Ultimately, we hope our methods will become valuable tools for preventing future outbreaks, whether in human or veterinary health. We are thrilled to embark on this journey and look forward to the discoveries ahead!
